TopicTitle: [Stock-Craft]A-5 Dagger: Interceptor Performance, Weapons, and Features Demonstration

Articles.Content:
Greetings and good day!

Here we have another craft from Guzworks: the A-5 Dagger. This craft is designed for atmospheric flight using air-breathing Basic Jet Engines. The A-5 Dagger is designed for low-altitude (10km and below) pursuit flight and attacks on large targets. It's usual armament of R-14 Mischief Guided Rockets are supersonic and can be controlled for precision attacks if necessary. The A-5 Dagger is the choice for short-range defense and escort missions and works best in numbers, so grab a few today!

Please see the stats, picture, and demo video below. Thank you for your time, and consider acquiring an A-5 for your interceptor needs today!

Name: A-5 Dagger

Type: Interceptor

Cost: 34,710

Mass (Dry): 8806 kg (8.806t)

Mass (No Payload): 10006 kg (10.006t)

Max Test Payload: 2002 kg (2.002t)

Tested Max. Takeoff Mass: 12008 kg (12.008t)

Cruise Alt. (Safe): 10,000m (10km)

Cruise Speed: 425 m/s

Ceiling (Max Achieved): 11147m (11.147km)

Max Speed Achieved: 440 m/s

Max Tested G-Force: 10.9G

Download Link:

https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/9743897/KSP/A-5%20Dagger.craft (Right-Click, Save-As...) <My Spaceport is just silly at the moment...so sorry!!!>

Tips for Operation:

This thing accelerates very fast on the runway. It has a short take-off speed and you MUST take advantage of it, or you will do some horrible crash thing on the runway. When you reach 40-50 m/s, start trying to take off. As for landing, you do not want to be going any faster than 65 m/s maximum. Give yourself a lot of time on your approach to the runway and bleed off as much speed as you can (see video). Don't flare too much, or you will ascend again (this thing can really glide). Always fly with ASAS ON. Things will get messy otherwise.

The A-5 Dagger is capable of some wicked turns. It can pull very high-G turns and even pull off full throttle vertical loops with. I pulled one with 10.9G! For tighter turns, throttle down to 25%-50%. About halfway though the turn, throttle all the way back up and cruise into the trajectory you want. All depends on the maneuver you're looking for and at what speed.

The craft can get up to 425+ m/s at 9-10km altitude. If you're looking for faster, longer travel, this is the way to go, but the fuel consumption steadily climbs. I have not tested too much about 10km, so please be careful! As well, it is ill-advised to perform high degree maneuvers at cruise altitude; it is likely to stall the engines.

Controls:

1, 2, 3 - M-14 Mischief Missiles (fired in pairs)

R (RCS) - Dual-Forward Antennae (Communications)

Backspace (Abort) - Initiate A.S.S. (Advanced Separation System) A.K.A.: Eject

Edited March 10, 2014 by guz667
Great plane. I always like video demonstrations.

I'm really glad you like it! I like to do videos because I can show what I really want people to see about a craft rather than tell, and I think it works out better. If you like video demonstrations, please subscribe! I'm trying to put some more time into videos (and always welcome critique).
